Header: Chinese man who swims along border sees benefit in a more open North Korea
Content: Every day, fitness enthusiast and Dandong resident Li Yongzhi squeezes on a pair of fins, secures a pair of goggles and plunges into the Yalu river for a morning swim along the border between China and North Korea. Despite decades of reported tensions, North Korean nuclear and missile tests and a widening economic gap between the two countries, ploughing through the often murky waters that divide them has never been an issue for Li, 69, and his fellow swimmers. Climbing onto North Korean soil, however, has always been forbidden. For Li, it makes sense for North Korea to open up its borders to China, its main trading partner and ally.
